In developing and supporting your position, you should consider the possible consequences of implementing the policy and explain how these consequences shape your position.

question1.passage: Rural households have more purchasing power than do urban or suburban households at the same income level, since some of the income urban and suburban households use for food and shelter can be used by rural households for other needs.
question1.questionText: Which of the following inferences is best supported by the statement made above?
options: The average rural household includes more people than does the average urban or suburban household.
Rural households have lower food and housing costs than do either urban or suburban households.
Suburban households generally have more purchasing power than do either rural or urban households.
The median income of urban and suburban households is generally higher than that of rural households.
All three types of households spend more of their income on food and housing than on all other purchases combined.
correctAnswer: Rural households have lower food and housing costs than do either urban or suburban households.
question1.explanation: The answer is (B). If the greater purchasing power of rural households results from their having more money left over after meeting basic expenses, it follows, as B says, that those expenses are lower for those households than they are for suburban or urban households at the same income level. Consequently, B is the best answer. A is not a supported inference, since there is no information to suggest that larger households are not more likely to have either more purchasing power or lower food and shelter expenses. C and D are not supported, since the passage compares only households that share the same income level. Because the relative amounts spent on different types of expenditures are not specified for any of the categories of households, E is not supported.

question2.passage: Upwards of a billion stars in our galaxy have burnt up their internal energy sources, and so can no longer produce the heat a star needs to oppose the inward force of gravity. These stars, of more than a few solar masses, evolve, in general, much more rapidly than does a star like the Sun. Moreover, it is just these more massive stars whose collapse does not halt at intermediate stages (that is, as white dwarfs or neutron stars). Instead, the collapse continues until a singularity (an infinitely dense concentration of matter) is reached. It would be wonderful to observe a singularity and obtain direct evidence of the undoubtedly bizarre phenomena that occur near one. Unfortunately in most cases a distant observer cannot see the singularity; outgoing light rays are dragged back by gravity so forcefully that even if they could start out within a few kilometers of the singularity, they would end up in the singularity itself.
question2.questionText: The author’s primary purpose in the passage is to
options: describe the formation and nature of singularities
explain why large numbers of stars become singularities
compare the characteristics of singularities with those of stars
explain what happens during the stages of a singularity’s formation
imply that singularities could be more easily studied if observers could get closer to them
correctAnswer: describe the formation and nature of singularities
question2.explanation: The passage on the whole deals with singularities and their formation.

question3.passage: Upwards of a billion stars in our galaxy have burnt up their internal energy sources, and so can no longer produce the heat a star needs to oppose the inward force of gravity. These stars, of more than a few solar masses, evolve, in general, much more rapidly than does a star like the Sun. Moreover, it is just these more massive stars whose collapse does not halt at intermediate stages (that is, as white dwarfs or neutron stars). Instead, the collapse continues until a singularity (an infinitely dense concentration of matter) is reached. It would be wonderful to observe a singularity and obtain direct evidence of the undoubtedly bizarre phenomena that occur near one. Unfortunately in most cases a distant observer cannot see the singularity; outgoing light rays are dragged back by gravity so forcefully that even if they could start out within a few kilometers of the singularity, they would end up in the singularity itself.
question3.questionText: The passage suggests which of the following about the Sun?
options: The Sun could evolve to a stage of collapse that is less dense than a singularity.
In the Sun, the inward force of gravity is balanced by the generation of heat.
The Sun emits more observable light than does a white dwarf or a neutron star.
correctAnswer: The Sun could evolve to a stage of collapse that is less dense than a singularity.
In the Sun, the inward force of gravity is balanced by the generation of heat.
question3.explanation: The passage clearly states that 'These stars, of more than a few solar masses, evolve, in general, much more rapidly than does a star like the Sun. Moreover, it is just these more massive stars whose collapse does not halt at intermediate stages (that is, as white dwarfs or neutron stars). Instead, the collapse continues until a singularity (an infinitely dense concentration of matter) is reached.'

question4.passage: Upwards of a billion stars in our galaxy have burnt up their internal energy sources, and so can no longer produce the heat a star needs to oppose the inward force of gravity. These stars, of more than a few solar masses, evolve, in general, much more rapidly than does a star like the Sun. Moreover, it is just these more massive stars whose collapse does not halt at intermediate stages (that is, as white dwarfs or neutron stars). Instead, the collapse continues until a singularity (an infinitely dense concentration of matter) is reached. It would be wonderful to observe a singularity and obtain direct evidence of the undoubtedly bizarre phenomena that occur near one. Unfortunately in most cases a distant observer cannot see the singularity; outgoing light rays are dragged back by gravity so forcefully that even if they could start out within a few kilometers of the singularity, they would end up in the singularity itself.
question4.questionText: Which of the following sentences would most probably follow the last sentence of the passage?
options: Thus, a physicist interested in studying phenomena near singularities would necessarily hope to find a singularity with a measurable gravitational field.
Accordingly, physicists to date have been unable to observe directly any singularity.
It is specifically this startling phenomenon that has allowed us to codify the scant information currently available about singularities.
Moreover, the existence of this extraordinary phenomenon is implied in the extensive reports of several physicists.
Although unanticipated, phenomena such as these are consistent with the structure of a singularity.
correctAnswer: Accordingly, physicists to date have been unable to observe directly any singularity.
question4.explanation: The last line of the passage states that: 'Unfortunately in most cases a distant observer cannot see the singularity; outgoing light rays are dragged back by gravity so forcefully that even if they could start out within a few kilometers of the singularity, they would end up in the singularity itself,' hence B would follow.

question5.passage: Since 1953, many experimental attempts to synthesize the chemical constituents of life under 'primitive Earth conditions' have been performed, but none of these experiments has produced anything approaching the complexity of the simplest organism. They have demonstrated, however, that a variety of the complex molecules currently making up living organisms could have been present in the early ocean and atmosphere, with only one limitation: such molecules are synthesized far less readily when oxygen-containing compounds dominate the atmosphere. Therefore some scientists postulate that the Earth's earliest atmosphere, unlike that of today, was dominated by hydrogen, methane, and ammonia. From these studies, scientists have concluded that the surface of the primitive Earth was covered with oceans containing the molecules fundamental to life. Although, at present, scientists cannot explain how these relatively small molecules combined to produce larger, more complex molecules, some scientists have precipitously ventured hypotheses that attempt to explain the development, from larger molecules, of the earliest self-duplicating organisms.
question5.questionText: According to the passage, which of the following can be inferred about the process by which the chemical constituents of life were synthesized under primitive Earth conditions?
options: The synthesis is unlikely to occur under current atmospheric conditions.
The synthesis is common in modern laboratories.
The synthesis occurs more readily in the atmosphere than in the ocean.
correctAnswer: The synthesis is unlikely to occur under current atmospheric conditions.
question5.explanation: On the basis of these lines: 'such molecules are synthesized far less readily when oxygen-containing compounds dominate the atmosphere. Therefore some scientists postulate that the Earth's earliest atmosphere, unlike that of today, was dominated by hydrogen, methane, and ammonia. It can be inferred that the synthesis is unlikely to occur under current atmospheric conditions.'

question6.questionText: In the early twentieth century, the discovery of radium ______ the popular imagination; not only was its discoverer, Marie Curie, idolized, but its market value exceeded that of the rarest gemstone.
question6.explanation: The idolization of the discoverer of radium and the increase in its market value shows that the discovery of radium was regarded as a great phenomenon which led to the arousal of the popular imagination. The words which best describe 'arousal' are 'enflamed' and 'stirred up'.

question7.questionText: In the early twentieth century, the discovery of radium ______ the popular imagination; not only was its discoverer, Marie Curie, idolized, but its market value exceeded that of the rarest gemstone.
question7.explanation: The idolization of the discoverer of radium and the increase in its market value shows that the discovery of radium was regarded as a great phenomenon which led to the arousal of the popular imagination. The words which best describe 'arousal' are 'enflamed' and 'stirred up'.

question8.questionText: Despite claims that his philosophy can be traced to a single source, the philosophy in fact draws liberally on several traditions and methodologies and so could justifiably be termed ______.
question8.explanation: The phrase 'draws liberally on several traditions and methodologies' indicates that the philosophy is liberal and all-inclusive, i.e., having extracted things from many traditions and cultures. The words closely related to the phrase 'liberal and all-inclusive' are 'catholic' and 'eclectic'.

question9.questionText: Job failure means being fired from a job, being asked to resign, or leaving voluntarily to protect yourself because you had very strong evidence that one of the first two was ______.
question9.explanation: The sentence indicates that a person leaves a job by one's own choice to avoid the shame of job failure, caused when he is either dismissed (fired) from the job or asked to resign from it. The choice of leaving the job on one's own is made because it is not disgraceful when compared to the other two job failures and also when the person wants to protect himself from the disgrace as he has proof that one of the other two job failures might be coming. The words closest in meaning to 'coming' are 'impending' and 'approaching'.

question10.questionText: Though (i) ______ to some degree, telling a small lie sometimes enables one to avoid (ii) ______ another's feelings.
question10.explanation: Though is a contrast sign, but telling a lie can't be good no matter what the circumstances. So the first blank has to be 'regrettable' as 'attractive' will not fit the sentence stylistically. Since the second part says 'telling a small lie,' logically it cannot be all that 'difficult.' The second blank is answered by 'harming' but not by 'mollifying' as here it can only be used in the sense of 'make less intense.' You can mollify someone's anger but stylistically you cannot mollify someone's feelings. You can't avoid considering someone's feelings either by telling a small lie.

question11.questionText: The problem with (i) _______ cinema is this: it gives rise to a new kind of idolatry i.e., idolizing the ridiculous as (ii) _______. The public which (iii) _______ its thirst with inanities and mistakes the bogus for truth will get over this obsession sooner or later, and this is when the problem will begin.
question11.explanation: The passage talks of some form of art in which you mistake 'bogus for truth.' By this logic, the two words that complete blank 2 and 3 are 'sublime' and 'sates.' This art form, from the given options in blank 1, has to be 'kitsch.'

question12.questionText: Doors were closing on our past, and soon the values we had lived by would become so obsolete that we would seem to people of the new age as _____ as travelers from an ancient land.
question12.explanation: Here the operative phrase is 'by would become so obsolete that we would seem.' The sentence is based on drawing a parallel between the first and the second part 'as travelers from an ancient land.' Look for any option that signifies past and you find 'quaint' (old fashioned) which complements the sentence beautifully.

question1.questionText: Given the existence of so many factions in the field, it was unrealistic of Anna Freud to expect any ______ of opinion.
question1.explanation: The presence of the phrase 'many factions' suggests that as there were a lot of groups (factions) present, it was not sensible (unrealistic) of Anna Freud to expect evenness and agreement in the opinions of the groups as each group with a different belief is bound to have a different opinion from the other. The words closest in meaning to 'evenness and agreement' are 'uniformity' and 'concord.'

question2.questionText: Although specific concerns may determine the intent of a research project, its results are often ______.
question2.explanation: The word 'although' indicates that the first part of the sentence is contrary to the second. The sentence indicates that although specific concerns may help to see the purpose (intent) of a research project, yet contrary to it, the results of the project cannot be seen or predicted. Thus, the results of the project remain 'unanticipated' and 'indefinite.'

question3.questionText: To list Reilly’s achievements in a fragmentary way is misleading, for it distracts our attention from the _____ themes of her work.
question3.explanation: To refer to Reilly’s achievements as incomplete (in a fragmentary manner) is deceiving because her works were not incomplete and used themes which dealt with all the details in a relevant manner. Thus, the themes of her work are 'integrating' and 'comprehensive.'

question4.questionText: People frequently denigrate books about recent catastrophes as morally despicable attempts to profit from misfortune, but in my view our desire for such books, together with the venerable tradition to which they belong, _____ them.
question4.explanation: The word 'but' indicates that the two parts of the sentence are opposite to each other. The sentence suggests that although the books about recent catastrophes (disasters) are defamed by the people, in reality, our desire for such books, along with the tradition worthy of respect (venerable) to which they belong, does not defame them but justifies them. The words closest in meaning to 'justifies' are 'legitimizes' and 'generates.'

question5.questionText: Because they have been so dazzled by the calendars and the knowledge of astronomy possessed by the Mayan civilization, some anthropologists have _______ achievements like the sophisticated carved calendar sticks of the Winnebago people.
question5.explanation: The key lies in 'Because they have been so dazzled.' Here 'because' is obviously a contrast sign, indicating that they couldn't see clearly, which in turn indicates that they were wrong in sidelining or ignoring 'achievements like the sophisticated carved calendar sticks of the Winnebago people.' 'Acknowledged,' 'defended,' and 'authenticated' would not work as they would imply that they did, indeed, give due consideration to the Winnebago. 'Described' is out of context. So we have 'overlooked' which has the same meaning as 'ignored.'

question6.questionText: If efficacious new medicines have side effects that are commonly observed and (i) ______, such medicines are too often considered (ii) ______, even when laboratory tests suggest caution.
question6.explanation: For the first blank, you can immediately discard 'salutary' because side effects cannot have salutary consequences. 'Unpredictable' also won't work because if they are commonly observed, then how can they be unpredictable? So the answer is 'unremarkable.' To answer the second blank, look at the last part 'even when laboratory tests suggest caution.' 'Even when' is a contrast sign and therefore we are looking for an antonym to caution. Now 'outdated' medicines will suggest caution, so will 'complicated,' but that doesn't even fit in stylistically. So 'safe' is the answer.

question7.questionText: The excitement died down in time, but the unfortunate Delpis, who was of a fundamentally (i) ________ disposition, found himself in the centre of a controversy. A certain art critic who inspected the work found it to be (ii) ________, Delpis though, claimed his innocence. His introverted nature earned him many enemies who turned (iii) ________ evidence against him by going to such lengths as planting evidence.
question7.explanation: In the first blank, the word is 'retiring' as we are told in the passage that Delpis is introverted. For the second blank, we need a negative word as Delpis is accused of something. This sense is conveyed by 'spurious.' And for the last blank, the word is 'circumstantial' as we are talking about evidence that has been planted. The other two options don't make sense.

question8.questionText: Just as hundreds of terminals connected to a supercomputer (i) ________ work independently, even though their actual control lies with the supercomputer, we as individuals may seem to have (ii) ________ opposite personalities but the seeds of these (iii) ________ spring from the same source.
question8.explanation: The first blank can be completed with 'seemingly' in keeping with the imagery of the lines. The second blank can be logically completed with 'diametrically' as the other two options don't make sense. And the last blank can be completed with 'traits' as we are talking about qualities of human beings.

question9.passage: Some modern anthropologists hold that biological evolution has shaped not only human morphology but also human behavior. The role those anthropologists ascribe to evolution is not of dictating the details of human behavior but one of imposing constraints—ways of feeling, thinking, and acting that 'come naturally' in archetypal situations in any culture. Our 'frailties'—emotions and motives such as rage, fear, greed, gluttony, joy, lust, love—may be a very mixed assortment, but they share at least one immediate quality: we are, as we say, 'in the grip' of them. And thus they give us our sense of constraints. Unhappily, some of those frailties—our need for ever-increasing security among them—are presently maladaptive. Yet beneath the overlay of cultural detail, they, too, are said to be biological in direction, and therefore as natural to us as are our appendixes. We would need to comprehend thoroughly their adaptive origins in order to understand how badly they guide us now. And we might then begin to resist their pressure.
question9.questionText: The primary purpose of the passage is to present
options: a position on the foundations of human behavior and on what those foundations imply
a theory outlining the parallel development of human morphology and of human behavior
a diagnostic test for separating biologically determined behavior patterns from culture-specific detail
a practical method for resisting the pressures of biologically determined drives
an overview of those human emotions and motives that impose constraints on human behavior
correctAnswer: a position on the foundations of human behavior and on what those foundations imply
question9.explanation: The passage is about the foundations of human behavior and what they imply, like frailties, emotions, fears, etc.

question10.passage: Some modern anthropologists hold that biological evolution has shaped not only human morphology but also human behavior. The role those anthropologists ascribe to evolution is not of dictating the details of human behavior but one of imposing constraints—ways of feeling, thinking, and acting that 'come naturally' in archetypal situations in any culture. Our 'frailties'—emotions and motives such as rage, fear, greed, gluttony, joy, lust, love—may be a very mixed assortment, but they share at least one immediate quality: we are, as we say, 'in the grip' of them. And thus they give us our sense of constraints. Unhappily, some of those frailties—our need for ever-increasing security among them—are presently maladaptive. Yet beneath the overlay of cultural detail, they, too, are said to be biological in direction, and therefore as natural to us as are our appendixes. We would need to comprehend thoroughly their adaptive origins in order to understand how badly they guide us now. And we might then begin to resist their pressure.
question10.questionText: The author implies that control to any extent over the 'frailties' that constrain our behavior is thought to presuppose
options: that those frailties are recognized as currently beneficial and adaptive
that there is little or no overlay of cultural detail that masks their true nature
that there are cultures in which those frailties do not 'come naturally' and from which such control can be learned
a full understanding of why those frailties evolved and of how they function now
a thorough grasp of the principle that cultural detail in human behavior can differ arbitrarily from society to society
correctAnswer: a full understanding of why those frailties evolved and of how they function now
question10.explanation: The passage clearly states 'We would need to comprehend thoroughly their adaptive origins in order to understand how badly they guide us now. And we might then begin to resist their pressure,' hence (D) is the answer in which it is suggested that we need to fully understand our frailties to overcome them.

question11.passage: Some modern anthropologists hold that biological evolution has shaped not only human morphology but also human behavior. The role those anthropologists ascribe to evolution is not of dictating the details of human behavior but one of imposing constraints—ways of feeling, thinking, and acting that 'come naturally' in archetypal situations in any culture. Our 'frailties'—emotions and motives such as rage, fear, greed, gluttony, joy, lust, love—may be a very mixed assortment, but they share at least one immediate quality: we are, as we say, 'in the grip' of them. And thus they give us our sense of constraints. Unhappily, some of those frailties—our need for ever-increasing security among them—are presently maladaptive. Yet beneath the overlay of cultural detail, they, too, are said to be biological in direction, and therefore as natural to us as are our appendixes. We would need to comprehend thoroughly their adaptive origins in order to understand how badly they guide us now. And we might then begin to resist their pressure.
question11.questionText: Which of the following most probably provides an appropriate analogy from human morphology for the 'details' versus 'constraints' distinction made in the passage in relation to human behavior?
options: The ability of most people to see all the colors of the visible spectrum as against most people’s inability to name any but the primary colors
The ability of even the least fortunate people to show compassion as against people’s inability to mask their feelings completely
The ability of some people to dive to great depths as against most people’s inability to swim long distances
The psychological profile of those people who are able to delay gratification as against people’s inability to control their lives completely
The greater lung capacity of mountain peoples that helps them live in oxygen-poor air as against people’s inability to fly without special apparatus
correctAnswer: The greater lung capacity of mountain peoples that helps them live in oxygen-poor air as against people’s inability to fly without special apparatus
question11.explanation: Understand the question and the passage. It asks for an analogy between details and constraints. The passage says that evolution is responsible for the bigger things. How individuals respond is not evolution dependent, and by this logic, the only option that fits is E.

question12.passage: Some modern anthropologists hold that biological evolution has shaped not only human morphology but also human behavior. The role those anthropologists ascribe to evolution is not of dictating the details of human behavior but one of imposing constraints—ways of feeling, thinking, and acting that 'come naturally' in archetypal situations in any culture. Our 'frailties'—emotions and motives such as rage, fear, greed, gluttony, joy, lust, love—may be a very mixed assortment, but they share at least one immediate quality: we are, as we say, 'in the grip' of them. And thus they give us our sense of constraints. Unhappily, some of those frailties—our need for ever-increasing security among them—are presently maladaptive. Yet beneath the overlay of cultural detail, they, too, are said to be biological in direction, and therefore as natural to us as are our appendixes. We would need to comprehend thoroughly their adaptive origins in order to understand how badly they guide us now. And we might then begin to resist their pressure.
question12.questionText: It can be inferred that in his discussion of maladaptive frailties the author assumes that
options: evolution does not favor the emergence of adaptive characteristics over the emergence of maladaptive ones
any structure or behavior not positively adaptive is regarded as transitory in evolutionary theory
maladaptive characteristics, once fixed, make the emergence of other maladaptive characteristics more likely
the designation of a characteristic as being maladaptive must always remain highly tentative
changes in the total human environment can outpace evolutionary change
correctAnswer: changes in the total human environment can outpace evolutionary change
question12.explanation: It is stated in the passage that 'Our frailties—emotions and motives such as rage, fear, greed, gluttony, joy, lust, love—may be a very mixed assortment, but they share at least one immediate quality: we are, as we say, in the grip of them. And thus they give us our sense of constraints.' This suggests that we are talking about very strong emotions, the author also says that our frailties are 'maladaptive' which suggests that changes in the total human environment can outpace evolutionary change.

question13.passage: If the mall shared by the neighboring towns of Georgia and Surrey was relocated from the mall’s current, overcrowded complex in central Georgia to a larger, spacious and available building in central Surrey, the mall would then be within the walking distance of a larger number of shoppers. The reason for this is that there are many more people living in central Surrey than in central Georgia, and shoppers usually walk to the mall if it is located near their homes.
question13.questionText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the above argument?
options: Earlier, the mall was located between the towns of Georgia and Surrey and later moved to the present location in central Georgia.
The area covered by central Georgia is approximately the same as the area covered by central Surrey.
The building that is available in Georgia is smaller than the alternative building that is available in Surrey.
Most shoppers who visit this mall do not live in either the town of Georgia or the town of Surrey.
The distance that shoppers currently cover on foot to get to the mall is much farther than what is usually considered as walking distance.
correctAnswer: The area covered by central Georgia is approximately the same as the area covered by central Surrey.
question13.explanation: The answer is (B). In the given stimulus, it is proposed that the mall shared by the two towns—Georgia and Surrey—should be relocated to central Surrey. The question stem asks to identify the most strengthening argument. Option (B) suggests that the area covered by both the towns is 'approximately the same.' The argument clearly states that there are more people living in Surrey than in Georgia and if the area covered by both the towns is the same then the mall will be accessible to more shoppers. Also, the distance to the mall can be covered by walking. Option (A) refers to the mall’s earlier location. This has no impact on the present argument. Option (C) is incorrect because the conclusion in the argument is not based on the spaciousness of the building. Option (D) weakens the above argument as it suggests that most shoppers do not live in either town. This shakes the basis of the given argument. Option (E) pertains to what is usually considered as walking distance. This does not strengthen the argument because one does not know if the relocation of the mall will enable shoppers to walk a standard walking distance or not.

question14.passage: If the mall shared by the neighboring towns of Georgia and Surrey was relocated from the mall’s current, overcrowded complex in central Georgia to a larger, spacious and available building in central Surrey, the mall would then be within the walking distance of a larger number of shoppers. The reason for this is that there are many more people living in central Surrey than in central Georgia, and shoppers usually walk to the mall if it is located near their homes.
question14.questionText: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
options: Many more regular shoppers, who currently walk to the mall, live in central Georgia than in central Surrey.
The number of people living in central Surrey who would shop regularly if the mall was located there is smaller than the number of people living in central Georgia who currently shop regularly.
The number of shoppers going to the mall would continue to increase steadily if the mall was relocated to central Surrey.
Most people who either drive or take public transport to commute to the mall would continue to do so even if the mall was relocated to central Surrey.
Most people who currently walk to the mall would remain regular shoppers if the mall was relocated to central Surrey.
correctAnswer: The number of people living in central Surrey who would shop regularly if the mall was located there is smaller than the number of people living in central Georgia who currently shop regularly.
question14.explanation: The answer is (B). The main point of the argument is the relocation of the mall so that it is more accessible to shoppers who walk to the mall. Option (B) suggests that the number of shoppers in Surrey is smaller than the number of shoppers in Georgia. So, if the mall is relocated to central Surrey, it will reduce the number of shoppers. This clearly weakens the above argument. Option (A) strengthens the argument because it only states that more regular shoppers live in central Georgia. It does not explain the relationship with the relocation of the mall. Option (C) strengthens the given argument because it explains the positive impact of relocating the mall. Option (D) pertains to those shoppers who use private or public transport to access the mall. However, the given argument is about those shoppers who walk to the mall. So, this option has no impact on the given argument. Option (E) also has no impact on the argument because it suggests that relocation of the mall will have no impact on the shopping habits of the shoppers.

question15.passage: A classic debate in psychology revolves around the nature vs. nurture question. Researchers continue to study how genes and environmental factors interact to shape human behavior. The consensus is that both play crucial roles, with the relative importance varying depending on the trait or behavior under examination.
question15.questionText: Which of the following best summarizes the implications of the nature vs. nurture consensus described in the passage?
options: The debate between nature and nurture has been conclusively resolved in favor of genetics.
Human behavior is primarily determined by genetic factors, with environment playing a minor role.
The importance of nature vs. nurture varies depending on the specific trait or behavior being studied.
Researchers have largely abandoned the study of genetics in favor of environmental factors.
Human behavior is entirely unpredictable, and no patterns can be discerned regarding its origins.
correctAnswer: The importance of nature vs. nurture varies depending on the specific trait or behavior being studied.
question15.explanation: This question assesses the reader's ability to infer the implications of the consensus mentioned in the passage. Option C correctly summarizes that the importance of nature vs. nurture varies depending on the specific trait or behavior studied, which aligns with the passage's content. The other options either misrepresent the consensus or provide inaccurate statements. Therefore, the correct answer is option C.

question1.questionText: Frances uses letters a, e, i, o, u, k, l, m, and s to spell four-letter words. The words must have at least one consonant, they cannot have two consonants in a row, they cannot have two same vowels adjacent to each other in a row, and they must end in a vowel. How many words can Frances form?
question1.explanation:
There can be 4 cases, add all:
1) 4 consonants × 4 different vowels × 4 different vowels × 5 vowels = 320
2) 4 different vowels × 5 vowels × 4 consonants × 5 vowels = 400
3) 4 vowels × 4 consonants × 4 different vowels × 5 vowels = 400
4) 4 consonants × 5 vowels × 4 consonants × 5 vowels = 400
Hence, Answer = 320 + 400 + 400 + 400 = 1520

question2.questionText: The image above shows an equilateral triangle with a side length of 14, and a square with a side length of x. If the area of the square is three times the area of the triangle, what is x?

question3.questionText: In 7 years, Dale will be twice as old as Clive and Clive will be twice as old as Brett. Right now, the product of their ages is 225. How old will Clive be in 10 years?
question3.explanation:
D + 7 = 2(C + 7)

&

C + 7 = 2 (B + 7)

B × C × D = 225

3 eqns, 3 unknowns - solve

B = 1

C = 9

&

D = 25

question4.questionText: If x and y are positive numbers, what is the smallest value of 5(11 − x)^4 + 4(8 − y)^2+7 ?
question4.explanation:
5(11 − x)^4 + 4(8 − y)^2 + 7

Now, (11 − x)^4 and (8 − y)^2 can never be negative.

Hence, for the least value, they must be equal to "0"

Least value = 0 + 7 + 7 = 7

question5.questionText:
Column A: the area of a circle inscribed in a square whose perimeter is 40

Column B: the area of a square inscribed in a circle whose circumference is 12π
question5.quantityA: the area of a circle inscribed in a square whose perimeter is 40
question5.quantityB: the area of a square inscribed in a circle whose circumference is 12π
options: The relationship cannot be determined by the information given
question5.explanation:
circle inscribed in a square

P = 40

=> S = 10

S = D = 10

Area = πd^2/4

= 25π = 78.5

square inscribed in a circle

Circumference = πd

12π = πd

d = 12

d = diagonal of square

D = 12

Area = (D/√2)^2 = 72

question6.questionText:
If the government stops the grant and the expenditure pattern remains the same, then what will be the decrease in the money spent for the education of illiterate?
[INCOME: 1. Money from fund raising programmes, 2. Grant from the government, 3. Contributions from individuals, 4. Contributions from corporations, 5. Contributions as commodities. EXPENDITURE: 1. Education of the illiterate, 2. Food for the poor, 3.Management and salary of staff, Expenses to organise fund-raising programmes. Above charsts show the amounts of an NGO Income for the year 1998-1999 = $ 55]
question6.explanation:
Grant from govt. = 50/360 × 55 = $7.64

Money spent for education = 150/360 × 54 = $22.5

Reduction in expenditure = 7.64/55 × 22.5 = $3.13

question7.questionText: How much money is raised by fund raising programmes?
question7.explanation: Money raised = 140/360 × 55 = 21.39 mn

question8.questionText:
Column A: Area of AOB

Column B: 10π
options: The relationship cannot be determined by the information given
question8.explanation:
Area of AOB = (72/360) × π × (7)^2 = 9.8π

Hence, Quantity B is greater.

question9.questionText: At a bakery, customers can either buy a package containing 4 cookies for $3.60, or a package containing 8 cookies for $6.30. If the bakery sold 30 packages and made $140.40, how many cookies did they sell?
question9.explanation:
4 cookies = $3.60

8 cookies = $6.30

- 1 cookie = $3.60/4 = $0.90

- 1 cookie = $6.30/8 = $0.7875

Now,

140.40/0.90 = 156 & 140.40/0.7875 = 178.3

Cookies sold must be in the range of 156 to 178.

Hence, the answer is 168.

question10.questionText: There are 3 red and 4 green marbles in a bag. If two marbles are drawn at the same time, what is the probability that they are the same color?

question11.questionText: One of the two buses completes a journey of 300 miles in 7 1/2 hours and the other journey of 450 miles in 10 hours. The ratio of their average speed is:
question11.explanation:
First Bus speed = 300/(15/2) = 40 m/h

Second Bus speed = 450/10 = 45 m/h

Ratio = 40/45 = 8/9

question12.questionText: The cost of shipping a package is $4.50 plus $0.25 per pound plus $0.75 per cubic foot of volume. Matt has a package whose density is 12 pounds per cubic foot, and it costs a total of $7 to ship it. How many pounds does the package weigh?
question12.explanation:
Total cost = $7

Variable cost = Total cost - Fixed cost = $7 - $4.50 = $2.50

Now, Let the number of pounds = x

Volume in cubic feet = x/12

x * 0.25 + (x/12) * 0.75 = 2.5

Solving, we get x = 8 pounds

question1.questionText: Three coworkers won a prize money in a lottery and divided it as follows: Albert received 2/5 of the money, Brad received 1/3 of it, and Carlos received the remaining $120. What was the amount of the prize money?
question1.explanation:
Let total prize money = x

Share of Carlos = x - 2x/5 - 1x/3

120 = 4x/15

x = 450

question3.questionText:

Hence, the answer is A.

question4.questionText: If a runner in a marathon had the 37th fastest time and the 50th slowest time, how many runners finished the marathon?
question4.explanation:
37th from start and 50th from end

Total = 37 + 50 - 1 (because the same person is included twice)

= 86

question5.questionText: A company has 160 employees. 40% of the employees are part-time, and 30% of the employees are female. How many more full-time male employees are there than part-time female employees?
question5.explanation:
160 employees:

Part-time: 40% = 64

Full-time: 60% = 96

Male: 70% = 112

Female: 30% = 48

Since there is no relation given between the two tables, the answer is option 5.

question6.questionText: If (4x+y)(x+4y) = 25xy + 400, what is the value of |x-y|?

question7.questionText: The figure above shows three mutually tangent circles. The largest circle has a radius of 3, the medium-sized circle has a radius of 2, and the smallest circle has a radius of 1. If the centers of the circles are connected to form a triangle, what is the area of the triangle?
question7.explanation:
Sides of the triangle = 3, 4, 5 (Pythagorean triplet)

=> It is a right triangle with hypotenuse = 5

Area = 1/2 × 3 × 4 = 6

question9.questionText: The operation Ω is defined by the relation aΩb = √(a^2 + b^2). What is (10Ω1)Ω(4Ω2)?

question10.questionText: The figure above shows two circles of the same size inscribed within a 9 by 8 rectangle. What is the diameter of each circle?

question11.questionText: A, B, and C are distinct odd digits. ABAC represents a four-digit number that is divisible by 9. What is the difference between the largest possible value of ABAC and the smallest possible value?
options: There is only one such four-digit number divisible by 9.
question11.explanation:
For a number to be divisible by 9, the sum of its digits should be divisible by 9.

Hence, 2A + B + C is divisible by 9.

Least ABAC = 1719 (sum = 18)

Highest ABAC = 7371 (sum = 18)

Difference = 5652

Note: Sum = 27 can't be taken because the sum of 4 odd numbers is always even.

& sum = 36 can't be taken because, then A = B = C = 9.

question12.questionText: Which month showed the largest decrease in total imports over the previous month?
question12.explanation:
Total imports in Jan = 30 + 40 + 32 = 102

Feb = 31 + 37 + 34 = 102

March = 32 + 36 + 31 = 99

April = 34 + 36 + 31 = 101

May = 36 + 34 + 32 = 102

June = 38 + 34 + 31 = 103

Total = 202 217 191

Evidently, the largest decrease was in March.

tests.name: MJ Academy Practice Test
tests.description: This practice test consists of five sections: an Analytical Writing section, two Quantitative sections, and two Verbal sections

awa.prompt: No field of study can advance significantly unless it incorporates knowledge and experience from outside that field.
awa.instructions: Write a response in which you discuss the extent to which you agree or disagree with the statement and explain your reasoning for the position you take. In developing and supporting your position, you should consider ways in which the statement might or might not hold true and explain how these considerations shape your position.

question1.questionText: The astronomer and feminist Maria Mitchell's own prodigious activity and the vigor of the Association for the Advancement of Women during the 1870's belie any assertion that feminism was ___ in that period.
question1.explanation: The sentence suggests that assertions about feminism being inactive during the 1870s are belied by the activity of both Maria Mitchell and the association. Therefore, the correct answer choices should mean 'inactive' or 'resting', making 'dormant' and 'quiescent' the best fit.

question2.questionText: Only by ignoring decades of mismanagement and inefficiency could investors conclude that a fresh infusion of cash would provide anything more than a ___ solution to the company's financial woes.
question2.explanation: The sentence implies that investors who ignored long-standing issues might believe a cash infusion could provide more than a temporary or stopgap solution, which it actually would not. The best answers, 'temporary' and 'stopgap,' indicate solutions that are short-term and insufficient to fully resolve the problems.

question3.questionText: Jones was unable to recognize the contradictions in his attitudes that were obvious to everyone else; even the hint of an untruth was ___ to him, but he courted serious trouble by always cheating on his taxes.
question3.explanation: The sentence describes how Jones was offended by even the hint of untruth. The words closest in meaning to 'offensive' are 'repugnant' and 'anathema,' which make them the correct answers. The contradiction lies in the fact that he still cheated on his taxes despite finding untruths offensive.

question4.questionText: The chances that a species will persist are reduced if any vital function is restricted to a single kind of organ; ___ by itself possesses an enormous survival advantage.
question4.explanation: The sentence suggests that survival is more likely when a vital function is distributed among many organs rather than restricted to one. The words that best capture this sense of abundance and multiplicity are 'redundancy' and 'copiousness.'

question5.passage: When the same parameters and quantitative theory are used to analyze both termite colonies and troops of rhesus macaques, we will have a unified science of sociobiology. Can this ever really happen? As my own studies have advanced, I have been increasingly impressed with the functional similarities between insect and vertebrate societies and less so with the structural differences that seem, at first glance, to constitute such an immense gulf between them. Consider for a moment termites and macaques. Both form cooperative groups that occupy territories. In both kinds of society there is a well-marked division of labor. Members of both groups communicate to each other hunger, alarm, hostility, caste status or rank, and reproductive status. From the specialist's point of view, this comparison may at first seem facile—or worse. But it is out of such deliberate oversimplification that the beginnings of a general theory are made.
question5.questionText: Which of the following best summarizes the author's main point?
options: Oversimplified comparisons of animal societies could diminish the likelihood of developing a unified science of sociobiology.
Understanding the ways in which animals as different as termites and rhesus macaques resemble each other requires training in both biology and sociology.
Most animals organize themselves into societies that exhibit patterns of group behavior similar to those of human societies.
Animals as different as termites and rhesus macaques follow certain similar and predictable patterns of behavior.
A study of the similarities between insect and vertebrate societies could provide the basis for a unified science of sociobiology.
correctAnswer: A study of the similarities between insect and vertebrate societies could provide the basis for a unified science of sociobiology.
question5.explanation: The author's main point in the passage is that a comparison of insect and vertebrate society could lead to the amalgamated or unified science of sociobiology. He goes on to expound on this by doing a comparative analysis of termites and macaques.

question6.passage: When the same parameters and quantitative theory are used to analyze both termite colonies and troops of rhesus macaques, we will have a unified science of sociobiology. Can this ever really happen? As my own studies have advanced, I have been increasingly impressed with the functional similarities between insect and vertebrate societies and less so with the structural differences that seem, at first glance, to constitute such an immense gulf between them. Consider for a moment termites and macaques. Both form cooperative groups that occupy territories. In both kinds of society there is a well-marked division of labor. Members of both groups communicate to each other hunger, alarm, hostility, caste status or rank, and reproductive status. From the specialist's point of view, this comparison may at first seem facile—or worse. But it is out of such deliberate oversimplification that the beginnings of a general theory are made.
question6.questionText: The author's attitude toward the possibility of a unified theory in sociobiology is best described as which of the following?
question6.explanation: There is clearly a sense of guarded optimism. The author is not overly optimistic about the possibilities opened up by this new approach. If we look at how the passage concludes: 'From the specialist's point of view, this comparison may at first seem facile—or worse. But it is out of such deliberate oversimplification that the beginnings of a general theory are made.' It is clear that there is a sense of guarded optimism.

question7.passage: When the same parameters and quantitative theory are used to analyze both termite colonies and troops of rhesus macaques, we will have a unified science of sociobiology. Can this ever really happen? As my own studies have advanced, I have been increasingly impressed with the functional similarities between insect and vertebrate societies and less so with the structural differences that seem, at first glance, to constitute such an immense gulf between them. Consider for a moment termites and macaques. Both form cooperative groups that occupy territories. In both kinds of society there is a well-marked division of labor. Members of both groups communicate to each other hunger, alarm, hostility, caste status or rank, and reproductive status. From the specialist's point of view, this comparison may at first seem facile—or worse. But it is out of such deliberate oversimplification that the beginnings of a general theory are made.
question7.questionText: In discussing insect and vertebrate societies, the author suggests which of the following?
options: A distinguishing characteristic of most insect and vertebrate societies is a well-marked division of labor.
The caste structure of insect societies is similar to that of vertebrate societies.
There are significant structural differences between insect and vertebrate societies.
correctAnswer: A distinguishing characteristic of most insect and vertebrate societies is a well-marked division of labor.
There are significant structural differences between insect and vertebrate societies.
question7.explanation: There are significant structural differences as evident from the line 'I have been increasingly impressed with the functional similarities between insect and vertebrate societies and less so with the structural differences that seem, at first glance, to constitute such an immense gulf between them.' Additionally, both societies exhibit a well-marked division of labor, as mentioned in the passage.

question8.passage: A proposed change to federal income tax laws would eliminate deductions from taxable income for donations a taxpayer has made to charitable and educational institutions. If this change were adopted, wealthy individuals would no longer be permitted such deductions. Therefore, many charitable and educational institutions would have to reduce services, and some would have to close their doors.
question8.questionText: The argument above assumes which of the following?
options: Without the incentives offered by federal income tax laws, at least some wealthy individuals would not donate as much money to charitable and educational institutions as they otherwise would have.
Money contributed by individuals who make their donations because of provisions in the federal tax laws provides the only source of funding for many charitable and educational institutions.
The primary reason for not adopting the proposed change in the federal income tax laws cited above is to protect wealthy individuals from having to pay higher taxes.
Wealthy individuals who donate money to charitable and educational institutions are the only individuals who donate money to such institutions.
Income tax laws should be changed to make donations to charitable and educational institutions the only permissible deductions from taxable income.
correctAnswer: Without the incentives offered by federal income tax laws, at least some wealthy individuals would not donate as much money to charitable and educational institutions as they otherwise would have.
question8.explanation: The passage argues that charitable and educational institutions, part of whose income comes from donations, would be negatively affected if wealthy individuals could not count such donations as deductions from their income. The question asks you to identify an assumption of the argument—that is, something that has to be true in order for the evidence presented to establish the conclusion. Choice A is the best answer, since if this statement is false, all wealthy individuals would, even without the incentive provided by federal tax laws, donate as much money as they do now.

question9.questionText: The National Archives contain information so ______ that researchers have been known never to publish because they cannot bear to bring their studies to an end.
question9.explanation: The key phrase 'cannot bear to bring their studies to an end' implies that we need a negative word to fill in the blank. The information in the National Archives was never known to be published. The only negative words in the given options are 'repetitive' and 'divisive.' Of these two, 'divisive' is logically correct as it suggests that something in the information is controversial, hence the reason why it was never published.

question10.questionText: The primary tension in the novel is between Frankenstein and his monster, a doubling of the creature and his creator, suggesting that (i) ______ and (ii) ______ may not be the binary opposition that they appear to be. Put differently the monster is made both in the laboratory as well as by the society, whose rejection makes a monster out of the creature: this theme comes out even though what permeates the novel is the theme of the dark double or the (iii) ______.
question10.explanation: The first part of the question deals with 'binary opposites,' hence the words that fit in the first two blanks are 'monstrosity' and 'normalcy.' In the third blank, we have to talk about the 'dark double,' hence the word 'doppelganger' fits in.

question11.questionText: Perhaps because scientists have been so intrigued by dogs' superior senses of smell and hearing, researchers have long ______ their eyesight, assuming that they inhabit a drab, black-and-white world, devoid of color.
question11.explanation: The second part of the sentence holds the key: 'assuming that they inhabit a drab, black-and-white world, devoid of color.' Assumption without validation is negative, which is the tone of the sentence. It implies that scientists focused on only dogs' superior senses of smell and hearing, ignoring their eyesight. The closest word for this is 'underestimated,' making it the correct answer.

question12.questionText: Though extremely (i) ______ about his own plans, the man allowed his associates no such privacy and was constantly (ii) ______ information about what they intended to do next.
question12.explanation: The answer to the first blank is solved by 'the man allowed his associates no such privacy,' implying that the man was secretive while not allowing others to be so. 'Reticent' is the closest synonym for secretive. For the second blank, since the man was not secretive about finding out others' plans, 'soliciting' is the appropriate word.

question1.questionText: Exit poll and opinion polls have been (i) ______ by the audience. This is because of the wrong predictions made by the (ii) ______ at the show. The viewers cannot be fooled for long, indeed the chances of their loyalties remaining fixed are as (iii) ______ as the possibility of snow on a Christmas day in Chennai.
question1.explanation: The exit polls are inaccurate, therefore, they will be 'shunned' by the people. In the second blank, psephologists is the right word, as psephologists study elections. The third blank, 'remote,' is the only logically correct option as it reflects the low probability of something happening, similar to the slim chance of snow on a Christmas day in Chennai.

question2.questionText: Having sufficient income of her own constituted for Alice (i) ______ independence that made possible a degree of (ii) ______ in her emotional life as well.
question2.explanation: The first blank is answered by 'sufficient income of her own.' Income provides financial independence, so 'a financial' is the answer. For the second blank, the word 'extravagance' is the best fit, as it is related to a degree of freedom in emotional behavior. The phrase 'independence that made possible' suggests that the missing word should relate to freedom, making 'extravagance' the most appropriate choice.

question3.passage: To evaluate a plan to save money on office-space expenditures by having its employees work at home, XYZ Company asked volunteers from its staff to try the arrangement for six months. During this period, the productivity of these employees was as high as or higher than before.
question3.questionText: Which of the following, if true, would argue most strongly against deciding, on the basis of the trial results, to implement the company's plan?
options: The employees who agreed to participate in the test of the plan were among the company’s most self-motivated and independent workers.
The savings that would accrue from reduced office-space expenditures alone would be sufficient to justify the arrangement for the company, apart from any productivity increase.
Other companies that have achieved successful results from work-at-home plans have work forces that are substantially larger than that of XYZ.
The volunteers who worked at home were able to communicate with other employees as necessary for performing the work.
Minor changes in the way office work is organized at XYZ would yield increases in employee productivity similar to those achieved in the trial.
correctAnswer: The employees who agreed to participate in the test of the plan were among the company’s most self-motivated and independent workers.
question3.explanation: According to the passage, a limited trial of a plan had favorable results. The question asks you to identify information that indicates that those favorable results would not be reproduced if the plan were put into effect. Choice A is the best answer, since if it is true, then the employees who took part in the trial were the ones likely to do best work at home. So the trial’s results cannot be taken as representative of what would happen if the plan was extended to other employees.

question4.passage: For me, scientific knowledge is divided into mathematical sciences, natural sciences or sciences dealing with the natural world (physical and biological sciences), and sciences dealing with mankind (psychology, sociology, all the sciences of cultural achievements, every kind of historical knowledge). Apart from these sciences is philosophy. In the first place, all this is pure or theoretical knowledge, sought only for the purpose of understanding, in order to fulfill the need to understand its intrinsic and consubstantial to man. What distinguishes man from animal is that he knows and needs to know. If man did not know that the world existed, and that the world was of a certain kind, that he was in the world and that he himself was of a certain kind, he wouldn’t be man. The technical aspects of applications of knowledge are equally necessary for man and are of the greatest importance, because they also contribute to defining him as man and permit him to pursue a life increasingly more truly human. But even while enjoying the results of technical progress, he must defend the primacy and autonomy of pure knowledge. Knowledge sought directly for its practical applications will have immediate and foreseeable success, but not the kind of important result whose revolutionary scope is in large part unforeseen, except by the imagination of the Utopians. If the Greek mathematicians had not applied themselves to the investigation of conic sections, zealously and without the least suspicion that it might someday be useful, it would not have been possible centuries later to navigate far from shore. The first men to study the nature of electricity could not imagine that their experiments, carried on because of mere intellectual curiosity, would eventually lead to modern electrical technology, without which we can scarcely conceive of contemporary life. Pure knowledge is valuable for its own sake, because the human spirit cannot resign itself to ignorance. But, in addition, it is the foundation for practical results that would not have been reached if this knowledge had not been sought disinterestedly.
question4.questionText: The author points out that Greeks who studied conic sections
options: were forced to resign themselves to failure
were unaware of the value of their studies
correctAnswer: were unaware of the value of their studies
question4.explanation: The answer is (C). In the second paragraph, the author mentions the Greeks. He tells us that the Greeks investigated the conic sections enthusiastically and without the least suspicion that it might someday be useful. This statement implies that the Greeks had no inkling that what they were investigating would be used by the people living in the future. Option (A) and (B) are neither stated nor implied from the passage.

question5.passage: For me, scientific knowledge is divided into mathematical sciences, natural sciences or sciences dealing with the natural world (physical and biological sciences), and sciences dealing with mankind (psychology, sociology, all the sciences of cultural achievements, every kind of historical knowledge). Apart from these sciences is philosophy. In the first place, all this is pure or theoretical knowledge, sought only for the purpose of understanding, in order to fulfill the need to understand its intrinsic and consubstantial to man. What distinguishes man from animal is that he knows and needs to know. If man did not know that the world existed, and that the world was of a certain kind, that he was in the world and that he himself was of a certain kind, he wouldn’t be man. If the Greek mathematicians had not applied themselves to the investigation of conic sections, zealously and without the least suspicion that it might someday be useful, it would not have been possible centuries later to navigate far from shore. The first men to study the nature of electricity could not imagine that their experiments, carried on because of mere intellectual curiosity, would eventually lead to modern electrical technology, without which we can scarcely conceive of contemporary life. Pure knowledge is valuable for its own sake, because the human spirit cannot resign itself to ignorance. But, in addition, it is the foundation for practical results that would not have been reached if this knowledge had not been sought disinterestedly.
question5.questionText: The title below that best expresses the ideas of this passage is
options: A Little Learning is a Dangerous Thing
The difference between science and philosophy
question5.explanation: The answer is (D). This is because the passage starts with an explanation of different kinds of knowledge and then adds that humans are humans because they know and they have a desire to know more. The application of the knowledge acquired is also important. The second paragraph begins by stating that though application of knowledge is important, pure knowledge has more primacy. Knowledge that has only been gained for practical application has limited scope. The passage goes on to explain that pure knowledge is the foundation for practical results. Thus, it can be safely inferred that the author believes that learning is important for its own sake. Therefore, the suitable title of the passage would be 'Learning for its own sake.'

question6.passage: For me, scientific knowledge is divided into mathematical sciences, natural sciences or sciences dealing with the natural world (physical and biological sciences), and sciences dealing with mankind (psychology, sociology, all the sciences of cultural achievements, every kind of historical knowledge). Apart from these sciences is philosophy. But, in addition, it is the foundation for practical results that would not have been reached if this knowledge had not been sought disinterestedly.
question6.questionText: It can be inferred from the passage that to the author, man's need to know is chiefly important in that it
options: allows the human race to progress technically
encompasses both the physical and social sciences
has increased as our knowledge of the world has grown
question6.explanation: The answer is (D). The answer to this question is found in the first paragraph where it is stated that man would not be man had he not had the desire to know. Knowledge is what defines man. Therefore, it can be inferred from the passage that, to the author, man's need to know is chiefly important in that it defines man's essential humanity.

question7.passage: The emancipation of women, James Joyce told one of his friends, has caused the greatest revolution in our time in the most important relationship there is — that between men and women. Other modernists agreed: Virginia Woolf, claiming that in about 1910 human character changed, and, illustrating the new balance between the sexes, urged, Read the Agamemnon, and see whether...your sympathies are not almost entirely with Clytemnestra. D. H. Lawrence wrote, perhaps the deepest fight for 2000 years and more, has been the fight for women's independence. But if modernist writers considered women’s revolt against men’s domination one of their greatest and deepest themes, only recently – in perhaps the past 15 years – has literary criticism begun to catch up with it. Not that the images of sexual antagonism that abound in modern literature have gone unremarked; far from it. But what we are able to see in literary works depends on the perspectives we bring to them, and now that women – enough to make a difference – are reforming canons and interpreting literature, the landscapes of literary history and the features of individual books have begun to change.
question7.questionText: Select the sentence in the passage which implies that women are changing literary criticism by seeing literature from fresh points of view.
correctAnswer: But what we are able to see in literary works depends on the perspectives we bring to them, and now that women – enough to make a difference – are reforming canons and interpreting literature, the landscapes of literary history and the features of individual books have begun to change
question7.explanation: The following sentence from the second paragraph of the passage implies that women are changing literary criticism by seeing literature from fresh points of view: "But what we are able to see in literary works depends on the perspectives we bring to them, and now that women – enough to make a difference – are reforming canons and interpreting literature, the landscapes of literary history and the features of individual books have begun to change." The word 'reforming' indicates that women are changing literary criticism.

question8.passage: The emancipation of women, James Joyce told one of his friends, has caused the greatest revolution in our time in the most important relationship there is — that between men and women. Other modernists agreed: Virginia Woolf, claiming that in about 1910 human character changed, and, illustrating the new balance between the sexes, urged, Read the Agamemnon, and see whether...your sympathies are not almost entirely with Clytemnestra. D. H. Lawrence wrote, perhaps the deepest fight for 2000 years and more, has been the fight for women's independence. But if modernist writers considered women’s revolt against men’s domination one of their greatest and deepest themes, only recently – in perhaps the past 15 years – has literary criticism begun to catch up with it. Not that the images of sexual antagonism that abound in modern literature have gone unremarked; far from it. But what we are able to see in literary works depends on the perspectives we bring to them, and now that women – enough to make a difference – are reforming canons and interpreting literature, the landscapes of literary history and the features of individual books have begun to change.
question8.questionText: The author quotes James Joyce, Virginia Woolf, and D. H. Lawrence primarily in order to show that
options: before the twentieth century, there was little interest in women’s literature
modern literature is dependent on the women’s movement
the interest in feminist issues is not new
correctAnswer: the interest in feminist issues is not new
question8.explanation: The answer is (E). This is implied from the first line of the second paragraph wherein the author mentions that it is only now that literary criticism has begun to catch up with modernist writers. These modernist writers include James Joyce, Virginia Woolf, and D. H. Lawrence. Therefore, it is safe to say that the author mentions these writers because he wants to show that the interest in feminist issues is not new. It was also present in and around 1910.

question9.questionText: True spirituality is beyond thought, it is (i) ________ and, therefore (ii) ________. How can you describe something that is beyond comprehension? God is both the thesis and the antithesis: a synthesis that transcends all cycles of Hegelian dialectics. Indeed, God is the subject for which there is no (iii) __________.
question9.explanation: In the first blank the word is 'transcendent' as conveyed by the phrase 'beyond thought.' If something is beyond thought, it becomes 'incomprehensible,' which is the word in blank 2, and the only logical option to complete blank 3 is 'predicate.'

question10.questionText: Despite a string of dismal earnings reports, the two-year-old strategy to return the company to profitability is beginning to ______.
question10.explanation: The first part holds the key - 'Despite a string of dismal earnings reports' which is a contrast sign. It implies that although it has been bad so far, it's getting better. Hence 'work' is the only logical choice as other options A & B are negative and C & E do not fit in either logically or stylistically.

question11.questionText: Unfortunately, since courses in nutrition are often (i) ______ medical school curriculums, a family physician is (ii) ______ to be an enlightening source of general information about diet.
question11.explanation: The first blank is a negative word as supported by the phrase 'unfortunately.' Hence 'neglected' can be the only logical choice, as 'encountered among' and 'squeezed into' cannot exactly be unfortunate. Since courses in nutrition are ignored ('neglected'), the only logical option for the second blank is 'unlikely.' If they have not studied it formally, how can family physicians be expected to provide enlightening advice?

question12.questionText: Although the meanings of words may necessarily be liable to change, it does not follow that the lexicographer is therefore unable to render spelling, in a great measure, ______.
question12.explanation: The phrase 'Although the meanings of words may necessarily be liable to change' implies that the meanings might change but 'it does not follow that the lexicographer is therefore, unable to render spelling,' implying that lexicographers are able to retain consistent spellings. The remaining part 'in a great measure' indicates that we need a word that contrasts with 'change', making 'constant' the correct answer.

question13.questionText: The success of science is due in great part to its emphasis on (i) _______: the reliance on evidence rather than (ii) _______ and the willingness to draw conclusions even when they conflict with traditional beliefs.
question13.explanation: The second part 'the reliance on evidence' provides the answer to the missing word as reliance on evidence, irrespective of what one personally believes, affirms the fact that 'objectivity' is the answer. The second blank has to be a contrast to 'objectivity,' hence 'preconceptions' is the best answer.

question14.questionText: Faith in order to be faith, as opposed to proven knowledge, cannot be (i) _______ except through questioning itself. It is the (ii) ______ mystery and majesty of faith that it cannot be measured. Shipwreck all you know on the reef of rationality, then take a leap in the dark to faith, said Kierkegaard. Faith is the leap in the dark, the ultimate (iii) ______.
question14.explanation: The passage looks into the nature of faith. Proven knowledge is the key phrase in the passage. If faith is not proven, then the word has to be 'validated' in the first blank. For the second blank, the mystery of faith would be 'unfathomable' as you cannot measure faith. The third blank must have a word that means surprise or unexpected as the phrase before it is 'leap in the dark,' hence the word 'cliffhanger'.

question15.passage: Corporate officers and directors commonly buy and sell, for their own portfolios, stock in their own corporations. Generally, when the ratio of such inside sales to inside purchases falls below 2 to 1 for a given stock, a rise in stock prices is imminent. In recent days, while the price of MEGA Corporation stock has been falling, the corporation’s officers and directors have bought up to nine times as much of it as they have sold.
question15.questionText: The facts above best support which of the following predictions?
options: The imbalance between inside purchases and inside sales of MEGA stock will grow even further.
Inside purchases of MEGA stock are about to cease abruptly.
The price of MEGA stock will soon begin to go up.
The price of MEGA stock will continue to drop, but less rapidly.
The majority of MEGA stock will soon be owned by MEGA’s own officers and directors.
correctAnswer: The price of MEGA stock will soon begin to go up.
question15.explanation: Since MEGA’s officers and directors have bought almost nine times as much of MEGA’s stock as they have sold, the ratio of inside sales to inside purchases is roughly 1 to 9, well below 2 to 1. Hence, by the generalization stated in the passage, a rise in MEGA’s stock price is imminent, and choice C is the best answer. The prediction in choice D contradicts the passage’s generalization, and choices A, B, and E are not supported by the facts.

question1.questionText: An alloy of zinc, aluminium & copper has them in ratio 1/2 : 1/3 : 1/5 respectively. What is the approximate percentage of aluminium in the alloy?
question1.explanation:
Zinc : copper : aluminium = 1/2 : 1/3 : 1/5

Simplifying the fractions:

Zinc : copper : aluminium = 30 : 30 : 30
= 15 : 10 : 6

Hence, calculate and find the percentage for aluminium.

question2.questionText: One root of x² + Kx - 8 = 0 is the square of the other. Then the value of K is:
question2.explanation:
The given equation is x² + Kx - 8 = 0.

Let one root be x and the other root be x².
Substitute into the quadratic equation to find the value of K.
After solving, the values of x are 4 and -2.
Thus, the value of K is -2.

options: The relationship cannot be determined by the information given.
question3.explanation:
In Triangle ABC:
60° + 3y + 2x = 180°

In Triangle DBC:
3y + x + 90° = 180°

Solving both equations, we get y = 20°.

question4.questionText: How many numbers greater than 4000 can be made, using 2, 3, 4 & 5? (Repetition allowed)
question4.explanation:
To form numbers greater than 4000, the first digit must be 4 or 5 (2 possibilities), and the remaining three digits can be any of the four digits (2, 3, 4, 5), so:

4 → 4 × 4 × 4 × 4 = 64

5 → 4 × 4 × 4 × 4 = 64

Total = 64 + 64 = 128.

question5.questionText: 3 fair coins are tossed, What’s the probability of getting at least 2 heads?
question5.explanation:
The total number of outcomes when tossing 3 coins is 2^3 = 8.

The favorable outcomes for at least 2 heads are: HHT, HTH, THH, HHH (4 outcomes).

Thus, the probability is 4/8 = 1/2.

question6.questionText: If a/3 = b/4 = c/7, then (a + b + c)/c is:
question6.explanation:
Given a/3 = b/4 = c/7, solve for a, b, and c in terms of a common variable (k).

From the equations, a = 3k, b = 4k, and c = 7k.

Substituting these into (a + b + c)/c:

(3k + 4k + 7k)/7k = 2.

question7.questionText: If the S.P. of an article is 4/3 times its C.P., the profit percent is:
question7.explanation:
Let C.P. = 3 units. Then, S.P. = 4 units.

Profit = S.P. - C.P. = 4 - 3 = 1 unit.

Profit percent = (Profit/C.P.) × 100 = (1/3) × 100 = 33 1/3%.

question8.questionText: Find the value of x ∠ABC = x
question8.explanation: In a cyclic quadrilateral, opposite angles are supplementary. Given the angle at point D as 25° and the angle at point A as 65°, their sum is 90°, so ∠ABC must be 90°.

question9.questionText: What is the area of a rectangle whose area is equal to the area of a circle with perimeter 24π? (Use π = 22/7)
question9.explanation:
The perimeter (circumference) of the circle is given by 24π, where π = 22/7. The formula for the circumference is C = 2πr. Solving for r:

24π = 2πr
r = 12

Now, calculate the area of the circle using A = πr²:

A = (22/7) × 12² = 452.57.

Thus, the area of the rectangle is also 452.57.

question10.questionText: Which of these is exactly divisible by 99?
question10.explanation: Among the given numbers, 114345 is exactly divisible by 99, as it satisfies the divisibility rule for 99 (which involves checking divisibility by both 9 and 11).

question11.questionText: The total size of market has increased from Rs.150 crore in 2002 to Rs.375 crore in 2003. What is the percentage increase in sales of the overall detergent market in 2003 over 2002?
question11.explanation:
The total size of the detergent market increased from Rs.150 crore in 2002 to Rs.375 crore in 2003.

The percentage increase is calculated as:

((375 - 150) / 150) × 100 = 150%.

question12.questionText: What is the growth rate of HLL detergents in 2003?
question12.explanation:
The market share of HLL in 2002 was 30%, and in 2003 it was 40%. The total size of the market increased from Rs.150 crore in 2002 to Rs.375 crore in 2003.

Growth rate is calculated as:

((40/100) × 375 - (30/100) × 150) / ((30/100) × 150) × 100 = 233%.
